50.heading: Outcasts.
50.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
50.author: [No author]

51.heading: Outcasts.
51.title: "Doe Eyes"
51.author: Joe Sinnott
notes: Begins: "Arrowhead, the renegade! Reckon I'll collect."

Summary: Arrowhead is branded as a renegade by the White man, and also is an outcast from his Pawnee tribe. He waits, longing to catch sight of his beloved Doe Eyes, the Pawnee maid, as she picks berries. He is not the only one watching. Bounty hunter Joel Turk sees her and decides to bribe the invading Oglala Sioux tribe into kidnapping her. The Sioux attack the Pawnee village the next morning, and Arrowhead counterattacks. He is too late to prevent the kidnapping, so he follows the Sioux and waits for dusk to free Doe Eyes. The attempt is discovered but the Pawnee couple manages to escaped, taking Turk's horse with them. Arrowhead takes Doe Eyes home. She declares her love for him, but he tells her his life as an outcast is not one for her to share. He leaves, knowing she will never be safe as long as Turk is alive.

52.heading: Outcasts.
52.title: "The Greed Virus!"
52.author: [No author]
52.series: Sue and Sally Smith) 10 p. in Sue and Sally Smith, Flying Nurses, no. 54
notes: Begins: "The authorities at Morse Medical Center in the United States dispatched teams to the village in the foothills of the towering Andes Mountains in South America! The specific disease endangering the people there was typhoid, but they suffered from an ancient illness that ate at the soul as well as the body! They were poor, hungry, illiterate, and unloved. Outcasts, they considered themselves, and when Sue and Sally Smith appeared they submitted dumbly to their ministrations! As Paolo De Portega pointed out, they were more like cattle than human beings!"

notes: Reprints an Olderman lecture on the history of cartooning, with illustrations by Olderman, Thomas Nast, Herblock, Bill Mauldin, R.F. Outcault, Roy Crane, Chas. Addams, et al., and photos of Olderman and Arnold Ismach.

133.heading: Outcault, Richard Felton, 1863-1928--Miscellanea.
133.title: Nixie : index entry
133.author: [No author]
133.series: p. 28) in America's Great Comic-Strip Artists, by Richard Marschall

134.heading: Outcault, Richard Felton, 1863-1928--Miscellanea.
134.title: "Opper, Fifty Years a Funmaker"
134.author: by R
134.appears_in: F. Outcault. p. 13, 46 in Circulation, v. 5, no. 25 (July 1926).
notes: Item on Frederick Burr Opper, with an Outcault drawing of Happy Hooligan.

135.heading: Outcault, Richard Felton, 1863-1928--Miscellanea.
135.title: "The People Laugh"
135.author: John W
135.appears_in: Dodds. chapter 8 (p. 213-235) in his Everyday Life in Twentieth Century America (New York : Putnam, 1965).
notes: Summary: Discussion of humor magazines, comedians, satire and comics, with sample illustrations by Clare Briggs (When a Feller Needs a Friend), John Held Jr., Charles Schulz (Peanuts), R.F. Outcault (The Yellow Kid, Buster Brown), F. Opper (Happy Hooligan), R. Dirks (The Katzenjammer Kids), George McManus (Bringing Up Father), Bud Fisher (Mutt and Jeff), Frank King (Gasoline Alley), and mention of others.

136.heading: Outcault, Richard Felton, 1863-1928--Miscellanea.
136.title: R.F. Outcault : clipping file.
136.author: [No author]
notes: 1 portfolio : ill. ; 25 x 38 cm.
Collected at Michigan State University Libraries in the Russel B. Nye Popular Culture Collection's Popular Culture Vertical File (PCVF).

137.heading: Outcault, Richard Felton, 1863-1928--Miscellanea.
137.title: "Retour sur un Controverse : la Bande Dessinée avant
137.author: Thierry Groensteen
137.appears_in: p. 114-115 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 2 (Jan. 1997).
notes: (Comptes Rendus)
Reviews two books celebrating the centennial of comics: R.F. Outcault's the Yellow Kid (introduced by Bill Blackbeard), and The Comic Strip Century (edited by Blackbeard and Dale Crain).

138.heading: Outcault, Richard Felton, 1863-1928--Miscellanea.
138.title: "The Write Stuff" p. 48-55 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 4
138.author: [No author]
notes: Graphologist Ilyas Zeshan analyzes the handwriting of Charles Schulz, Milton Caniff, Harvey Kurtzman, Willard Mullin, Frank King, Bill Holman, Harold Foster, Steve Ditko, Rube Goldberg, Richard F. Outcault, Walt Kelly, Arnold Roth, Joe Shuster, and Frank Willard.
